title: Sand pouring into a moving cart

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A cart of width <math alttext="w" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>w</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and mass <math alttext="M equals , 200 , kg" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> moves horizontally on a flat track. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the right side of the cart is directly underneath a spout that begins emptying sand into the cart at a constant rate <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, measured in <math alttext="kg per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kg/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The speed of the cart as a function of time for the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t is less than or equal to , 1.75 , seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.75</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the graph, but after <math alttext="t equals , 2 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> the left side of the cart has not yet passed the spout. The wheels of the cart roll without slipping. (a) At what time does the speed of the cart reach <math alttext="1 meter per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain how you arrived at your answer.

frqParts.text: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A cart of width <math alttext="w" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>w</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and mass <math alttext="M equals , 200 , kg" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> moves horizontally on a flat track. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the right side of the cart is directly underneath a spout that begins emptying sand into the cart at a constant rate <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, measured in <math alttext="kg per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kg/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The speed of the cart as a function of time for the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t is less than or equal to , 1.75 , seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.75</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the graph, but after <math alttext="t equals , 2 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> the left side of the cart has not yet passed the spout. The wheels of the cart roll without slipping. (a) At what time does the speed of the cart reach <math alttext="1 meter per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain how you arrived at your answer.

A student analyzing the situation writes the equation <math alttext="a of t equals the fraction with numerator negative 5 , and denominator t squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> to model the acceleration that the cart has as a function of time starting at <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and ending at the time that the left edge of the cart passes under the spout.A student analyzing the situation writes the equation to model the acceleration that the cart has as a function of time starting at and ending at the time that the left edge of the cart passes under the spout.(b) Other than the fact that the acceleration is negative, identify one feature of the function <math alttext="a of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> shown above, that correctly models the motion of the train car. Justify your answer.

(c) Identify one feature of the function <math alttext="a of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> shown above that incorrectly models the motion of the train car. Justify your answer.

Now suppose that the student corrected their mistakes and has derived the correct equation for <math alttext="a of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and the rate <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that sand enters the cart.(d) The student wishes to calculate the total energy dissipated as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain how the student could do this using the correct function <math alttext="a of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and the other given information.

The experiment is repeated, except this time sand is emptied into the cart at a different rate. A student taking data obtains the speed <math alttext="v of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of the cart as a function of time. The student also knows the width <math alttext="w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>w</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the cart, the mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the cart,and the new rate <math alttext="R prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>′</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at which sand is drained into the cart.(e) Explain how the student could use the function and other information to calculate the rate at which kinetic energy is dissipated at the instant just before the left edge of the cart leaves the spout.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
